descriptions.description: Speak Business English Like an American

radioExercises.title: Choose the most appropriate response to the following:

question.text: 1. We’d better be careful what we say in the office.

options.option: a) That’s right. The walls have ears.
b) Likely story!
c) Right, I wasn’t born yesterday.

question.text: 2. Eric, we’re going to have to ask you to take a 40 percent pay cut. But next year, I promise we’ll triple your salary.

options.option: a) Lower your voice. The walls have ears!
b) Don’t get too excited. Chill out!
c) That’s hard to believe. I wasn’t born yesterday!

question.text: 3. Jill is constantly flattering her boss and offering to do favors for him.

options.option: a) Why doesn’t she butter him up instead?
b) Think twice before accepting favors from her.
c) That’s one way to climb the corporate ladder.

question.text: 4. I’m giving a presentation to our CEO in a half an hour. I’m so nervous!

options.option: a) Likely story.
b) Chill out!
c) You’re such a yes man.

question.text: 5. I spent three hours helping Rick with his financial projections, and he didn’t even say thank you.

options.option: a) You need to look at yourself in the mirror.
b) I’m sure you’ll think twice before helping him again.
c) He’s trying to climb the corporate ladder.

question.text: 6. Maria works at least 60 hours a week at the law firm and always volunteers for extra work. She’s an excellent employee.

options.option: a) She’ll definitely get ahead.
b) Let’s not talk about her behind her back.
c) It’s a dog-eat-dog world.

question.text: 7. Paul was arrested for stealing millions of dollars from his company.

options.option: a) I’m not surprised. He’s a real yes man.
b) That’s one way to climb the corporate ladder.
c) I don’t know how he can look at himself in the mirror.

question.text: 8. You’re the best boss I’ve ever had and definitely the smartest!

options.option: a) Are you just out for yourself?
b) Are you trying to butter me up?
c) Isn’t it a dog-eat-dog world?
